I got this first question wrong (I thought the tethered ping-pong ball's beaker would be heavier). This is because I failed to realize the change in tension on the dense ball when it was submerged. It's a great experiment and I feel like I learned something from watching it.

However, I do not like the explanation! Third law arguments always seem to involve force-pairs, but it really bugs me when these seem to be conjured one at a time only until a desired result is reached. On the left (ping-pong) we see a three-vector solution... that's an odd number...one of the vectors isn't getting paired.

Also, "The downward force on the water is almost entirely counteracted by the upward force of the tension of that string on the bottom of that beaker." Isn't that a bit like lifting yourself up by your own boot straps? Can this be right?? (Admittedly I answered the original question incorrectly, so, please tell me if I'm missing something). Let's say I added a coiled spring that happened to be the same density as water, and that it doubled the tension in the ping-pong ball's thread, would that therefore further reduce the weight of the beaker? What if a housefly (who happened to be only as dense as air) were trapped, sealed inside the ping-pong ball, flying upward with as much force as it could muster, pressing against the top? What if I replaced the ping-pong ball with a toy submarine of identical volume and density, but this toy had a propeller that spun vigorously, tripling the tension in the tether-thread, would that further reduce the weight of the beaker? In all these cases, the supposedly counteractive tension of the thread on the bottom of the beaker is increased, but I do not think any of them would alter the weight of the beaker.

The way I see it (again, please correct me if I'm wrong) is that each pan of that balance is supporting a certain similar-but-separate set of atoms. If we sum their weights, we find that everything is equal except for the atoms that make up the balls. Each (average) cubic millimeter of the solid ball weighs more than the same volume of the ping-pong ball, we total those weights, and subtract any other force from outside the beakers (none for the ping-pong ball, a small thread-tension for the dense ball).

Put another way, the values are identical to what we'd have measured if there were no buoyancy effects, the beakers were full of an equal mass of ice, and, resting atop the ice, were the balls, the dense one with just a tiny amount of tension holding it up (the difference between its weight and the weight of an equivalent volume of water) exerting a net downward force of the mass of the dense ball minus the small, supporting tension vector; and the ping-pong ball, whether just resting on the ice, stuck to the bottom with a slack piece of spider silk, or lashed to the bottom of the beaker with an extremely taught kevlar thread, in all cases exerting the same net gravitational force (i.e. g times the mass of the ping-pong ball (and the negligible mass of the thread, regardless of how tight or lose that thread might be)).

I don't see the tension of the ping-pong ball's thread as capable of making any difference to the overall weight of the beaker.

I also don't see the buoyancy negative pair vector (the "equivalent downward force on the water") as "pushing" the beaker (and, thus, the balance pan) downward and needing to be counteracted by some third (unpaired) internal tension vector. The ping-pong ball cannot push the water, beaker, or balance-pan downward by a force any greater than its own weight.

Again, I appreciate the experiment. I got it wrong and am trying to repair my intuition, please let me know if any of the above is off base on my part.

C. @Veritasium's explanation is a little complicated (I think).

The ping ball side is easy to figure out, it's simply the weight of the beaker, water, and ping pong ball (the tension in the string adds nothing because whatever it is, it cancels out).  The acrylic side is a little trickier.  Consider two empty beakers with the acrylic ball hanging into one of the (empty) beakers.  Which side weighs more?  Obviously they are equal--the acrylic ball doesn't add any force to the beaker.  As you fill the beakers with water, the acrylic ball begins to push down on it's beaker because of the buoyant force.  This essentially adds a weight to the acrylic beaker's side equal to the amount of water displaced. Which means the weight of the acrylic ball/side doesn't matter--only the volume does--as long as it's denser than water.

So clearly, the amount of water displaced is more than the weight of the ping pong ball, so that side is heavier.

The second question is trickier still.  Again, you clearly push down on the ping pong side since you have to push the ball into the water.  This obviously adds a force equal to the buoyant force--the amount of water displaced.  At first glance, it would appear that B is correct and the ping pong side should be heavier since you add the buoyant force plus the weight of the ping pong ball (even though it's small).

However, you don't actually add a force equal to the buoyant force.  This is because the mass of the ping pong ball already displaces some (albeit not very much) water.  So when you push down, you are adding a force equal to the total displaced water minus the amount the ping pong ball displaced (which exactly equals the mass of the ping pong ball).  So when you subtract out the weight of the ping pong ball, both sides end up pushing down with the same buoyant force (the amount of water displaced).

With the ping pong ball tethered to the bottom of the beaker, that side of the scale is identical to one in which the ball is untethered floating on the surface (hence not displacing water). The downward force on the ball is in the stored potential energy of the taut string, not by the acceleration of mass due to gravity. The acrylic ball, on the other hand, is applying a downward force - due to the pull of gravity on the mass of the ball - to displace the water, and hence truly adds weight to push down on that side of the scale. Acrylic Ball Side – Downward force equals the weight of the water plus the weight of the water displaced by the supported acrylic ball.  The acrylic ball is heavier (denser) than water.  Therefore, the supported acrylic ball adds just the weight of the water it displaces.

Ping Pong Ball Side – Downward force equals the weight of the water plus the weight of the water displaced by the submerged ping pong ball.  The ping pong ball is lighter (less dense) than water and thus floats.  Therefore, the floating ping pong ball adds just its weight.  Applying a downward force to sink the ping pong ball is equivalent to adding weight to the ball until it become as dense as water.  Objects with the same density as water displace an amount of water equal to the weight of the water it displaces.

Both beakers start with the same amount of water.  Both balls are the same size and therefore displace the same amount of water and in turn add the same weight of displaced water to each side of the scale.   

This is different from tying the ping pong ball down to the bottom of the beaker.  Tying the ping pong ball down introduces two forces to the system.  The downward tension force applied to the ping pong ball and the upward tension force applied to the bottom of the beaker.  These two forces are internal forces, equal and opposite, action-reaction forces, and therefore cancel out.   

The applied force from the finger is an external force and therefore provides the additional “weight” needed to make the ping pong ball “neutrally buoyant”.

Well, let's see what the real problem is. The balance really just compares the two forces on the two plates, which in most cases, weight of two objects. This is not quite the case here, but close enough. So the goal is to find the forces on the two plates, and compare them. 
On both sides there is a beaker and water, measured precisely enough to have the same weight on both sides, so they are not the interesting bit. The fun part is figuring out the force contribution from the balls. And there's a very important hint: they are both stationary. (for our purpose here, close enough to stationary) From that we can figure out what the water, the string, the finger, and the balls do exactly. Thanks to Archimedes we know the buoyant force is the same as water displaced, so if both balls are the same size and both completely submerged, the forces on water are the same. What the finger and the string do is basically changing their weights to the same as the water they displace.
So on the left, it's beaker, water, and a ball of water; on the right, it's beaker, water, and a ball of water.
So the answer is obviously not C, either A or B.

I like the follow explanation, because it is relatively 'foolproof' and also gives insight into the second question that was asked.  It is of course equivalent to the explanation given, but is basically has to be if it is to be correct. 

The intuition is this:  If it was not for the thread holding up the heavy ball, the problem would be very straightforward, since basically we simply have to tally the weight of things on each side of the balance.   So can we somehow morph the problem into this simpler case?   Yes.    Notice that the problem never tells us how dense the right ball is, because it happens not to matter.   Imagine you could change the density of the heavy ball at will so it starts out heaver than water., but could be made as light as the Ping-Pong ball if desired.   So as we decease the density of the ball, the force on the string decreases, and at some point goes to zero.   This happens to be when the ball has exactly the density of water. 

At that point there is no force on the thread.   Thus you can ignore it (cut the thread).   OK now we can simply tally up the weights on both sides.  On the one side we have the beaker, water, and the ping pong ball, and on the other we have the beaker, and the water and a ball with the density of water.   Clearly the later is heaver, and thus the balance on that side must go down.   Tada!

Now we can use this same idea for the second question, where the Ping-Pong ball is being forced from the top to be submerged.   So we imagine this ball can change density and we INCREASE the density until we can drop this force to zero.  Again we find that this happen when the density of the ball is that of water.    Again we simply tally what is on both sides.   In this case however BOTH sides have a beaker, the water, and a ball with the density of water.  Thus both sides have the SAME weight and thus remain balanced.

Great video, as usual, although I think the explanation is difficult to follow for many. How about this:

The ping-pong ball tether is essentially a red herring. Buoyant force has nothing to do with overall force since it is INTERNAL to the ball/beaker system (it is taken up by the string). Essentially, its just the mass of the beaker, water, string, and PP ball no matter the configuration - the ball could be floating at the top with a piece of string thrown in and its the same mass.

However, the acrylic ball/beaker system has an EXTERNAL force - that of the tension in the string. Buoyant force DOES come into play here via Newton's 3rd Law. Water applies buoyant force onto ball, ball applies equal and opposite force back onto water thus making that side heavier. All the string does is take up some of the acrylic ball's weight (the part that the buoyant force doesn't cover).

I have drawn the free body diagram to solve the two problems. My answer is C, balanced.

In the original situation, the weight of the system at left-hand side is the sum of (downward buoyant reaction force by pingpong ball + beaker and water weight - the upward tension). Actually, the magnitude of the buoyant force on the pingpong ball is equal to the (pingpong ball weight + the downward tension). So, the total weight of the system becomes (pingpong ball weight+ beaker and water weight).

At right-hand side system, the weight is the sum of (downward buoyant reaction force + beaker and water weight), but no any tension force. The magnitude of the buoyant force on acrylic ball is equal to (acrylic ball weight - the upward tension). 

The downward buoyant reaction force is larger than the pingpong ball weight. So, the system at right-hand side is heavier then the system at left-hand side.

In the second situation, the weight of the system at left-hand side is the sum of (downward buoyant reaction force + beaker and water weight), no matter with the force act by the fingers. Because the two balls have the same size, their buoyant reaction forces to the system is the same. Therefore, both side have the same weight. The answer is definitely C, balanced.

Any time you put a Ping-Pong ball in water, its tendency is to displace a smaller amount of water than an acrylic ball, so that the buoyant force is low enough to match the weight of the ping-pong ball and displaced water. (The small amount of displaced water adds a small weight, which is probably negligible but I'll call it w.) You can only counteract that tendency with an external force, such as tension or submerging it manually. The increase in external force matches the increase in buoyant force. Thus the net buoyant force remains the same, and the weight of the ping-pong ball (plus w from earlier parenthetical) exactly opposes it in equal measure.
The acrylic ball cannot be brought to equilibrium. When you submerge it, the tendency is not to go up to counteract the buoyant force. The tendency is for the ball to go down, because the weight surpasses the buoyant force. In the ping-pong–ball system, the net force was upward because the weight was less than the buoyant force; here it is down. Because of this, the acrylic-ball system is not in equilibrium and the net force is equal to the weight of the acrylic ball. The tension and buoyant force oppose the weight of the acrylic ball, and the force of the water displaced is unopposed except by holding the scale balanced (although the buoyant force equals that weight of the water).
So the net force on the left is the weight of the ping-pong ball (plus w) and the net force on the right is the weight of displaced water.

C. When comparing the normal forces on the two beakers (this is what the balances are comparing), it turns out that F_NL (normal force on the left beaker) is the same as F_NR (normal force on the right beaker)

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
First considering the external forces on the left beaker:
-Weight of beaker and water (M*g)
-Weight of ping pong ball (m_p * g)
-Downward force of finger (F)
Since these all act downwards, they all have the same sign:
F_NL = M*g + m_p * g + F

In order to determine F, we consider the ping pong ball's force diagram:
-Weight of ping pong ball (m_p * g)
-Buoyancy force (F_B)
-Downward force of finger (F)
These must sum to zero since the ball isn't accelerating (and choosing up as +)
0 = - m_p * g + F_B - F
Solving for F gives:
F = F_B - m_p * g

Plugging this into our F_NL equation gives:
F_NL = M*g + m_p * g + (F_B - m_p * g)
F_NL = M*g + F_B

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
For the external forces on the right beaker:
-Weight of beaker and water (M*g)
-Weight of the acrylic ball (m_a * g)
-Upward force of tension from the string (F_T)
Here, the tension is opposite to the two weights, so it has the opposite sign:
F_NR = M*g + m_a * g - F_T

In order to determine F_T, we must consider the acrylic ball's force diagram:
-Weight of the acrylic ball (m_a * g)
-Buoyancy force (F_B), which is the same as for the ping pong ball (mentioned in the video)
-Tension force from string (F_T)
Again, these must sum to zero since the ball doesn't accelerate (and choosing up as +)
0 = - m_a * g + F_B + F_T
Solving for F_T gives:
F_T = m_a * g - F_B

Plugging this into the F_NR equation gives:
F_NR = M*g + m_a * g - (m_a * g - F_B)
F_NR = M*g + F_B

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Since F_NL and F_NR both equal the same thing, the balance will remain balanced.

At this moment, the left side of the scale only feels the weight of the beaker (Wbeaker) plus the weight of the ball (Wball), that is, Wbeaker+Wball. C. Balanced.

Acrylic Ball:
As we already know, the acrylic ball displaces a certain amount of water. This results in an upwards buoyant force on the acrylic ball which is, however, not enough to counteract its weight. The remaining force of the weight is taken by the string from which the acrylic ball is suspended.
Thus the net weight of the beaker containing the acrylic ball is the same as if there were no acrylic ball but the beaker had an additional water added to it whose volume is the same as the acrylic ball.

Ping pong ball:
The ping pong ball displaces the same amount of water as the acrylic ball, since they are the same volume. This results in an upwards buoyant force which is more than enough to counteract the weight of the ping pong ball (since it is filled with air). We then add an additional downward force on the ping pong ball to submerge it just under the surface of the water. This force is the same as if the beaker had only water and we added an additional volume of water equal to the volume of the ping pong ball.
Thus the net weight of the beaker containing the ping pong ball is the same as the net weight of the beaker containing the acrylic ball.

Some additional considerations:
If we push the ping pong ball further below the surface of the water, the net weight of its beaker will exceed the net weight of the beaker with the acrylic ball. In order for the scale to remain balanced, the ping pong ball must be only just submerged.

For anyone not understanding this, it also took me a while to figure out how it works. But I've got it now and have a good way of explaining it:

The beaker with the ping pong ball in is a closed, independent system. Whatever forces are exerted inside the beaker by the water and the tension in the string etc. makes no difference because the ball is tethered to the beaker itself so all internal forces balance out. Essentially you just have a beaker, some water, a ping pong ball and some string and the total weight is just the weights of the individual items added together.

In the case of the other beaker, because the acrylic ball is tethered to the outside world (not through the beaker) the forces don't cancel each other out. When the ball is submerged the water exerts a force on it in all directions, this is pressure, but we're only interested in the vertical forces. The overall vertical force is upwards, because the water pressure is higher at the bottom of the ball than the top of the ball because it's slightly deeper (think of the fact that the ball would sink slower than it would fall through air, so you know there is a force pushing the ball up, although not as high as the gravitational force pulling the ball down). This buoyancy force tries to push the ball upwards, but since the weight of the ball is greater, the force pushes the scales down instead. This force is equal to the weight of the water displaced by the ball i.e. a sphere of water exactly the same size as the acrylic ball( because that amount of water is forced above the ball), but more importantly, a sphere of water the same size as the ping pong ball.

Now all you have to ask yourself is which is the higher force, the weight of the ping pong ball and the string, or the weight of a sphere of water the same size as the ping pong ball. We know the ping pong ball is less dense than water, because it floats, so the buoyant force on the acrylic ball is higher than the weight of the ping pong ball (and the string, because it weighs so little), so overall this pushes down on the scales more on the acrylic ball side.

The force on the balance (N1) from the ping pong ball is:
N1 = Mb1*g + Mw*g + F
Mb1 is the mass of the ping pong ball, Mw is the mass of water, and F is the force from the hand.

The force from the acrylic ball side is:
N2 = Mb2*g + Me*g - T
Mb2 is the mass of the acrylic ball and T is the tension in the supporting string.

The force from the hand F can also be written as:
F = Fb - Mb1*g
Fb is the buoyancy force.

And T can be written as:
T = Mb2*g - Fb

So:
N1 = Mw*g + Fb
N2 = Mw*g - Mb2*g + 2Fb

If the acrylic ball were to sink, that would mean that N2 > N1, or N2 - N1 > 0.

So:
Mw*g - Mb2*g + 2Fb - Mw*g - Fb > 0

This simplifies to:
Fb - Mb2*g > 0
or
Fb > Mb2*g

We know this statement is false because the acrylic ball is more dense than the water so it's gravitational force is greater than its buoyant force. Therefore, N2 is not greater than N1. Rather, N1 > N2, so the balance would tip toward the ping pong ball.

Mathematically, the net force on the scale is Mg, where M is the mass of the beaker and water, plus mg, where m is the mass of the ball, plus F, where F is the force applied to the ball. Let:
M = mass of each beaker
V = volume of each ball = volume of water displaced by each ball when completely submerged in water
m1= mass of ping pong ball
m2 = mass of acrylic ball
UT = upthrust acting on each ball and therefore a downward force acting on each beaker (identical for both the balls because the density of water and volume of ball inside water is same)
X = downward force due to only the water present in both the beakers when the balls aren't there.
T = tension of string in the ping pong ball's beaker. T = UT - (m1)*g
g = acceleration due to gravity

///////////////CASE 1 (when there is thread to which ping pong ball is attached)///////
In the first case (when ping pong ball has string), net downward force on beaker containing ping pong ball was:
F1 = Mg + UT + X - T
using expression for T, we get F1 = Mg + UT + X - UT + (m1)*g = Mg + X + (m1)*g
Net downward force on beaker containing acrylic ball:
F2 = Mg + UT + X

Clearly, since (m1)*g < X. Beaker containing acrylic ball will go down (when there is thread supporting ping pong ball).
//////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////

///////CASE 2 (when ping pong ball is just submerged in water, without thread)///////////////////
Now, F2 remains unchanged. However, the tension T acting on beaker 1 is now absent. From ping pong ball's POV: F(finger) = UT - (m1)*g, but from the perspective of (beaker + water) system, it applies an upward UT on the ball, therefore an equal and opposite UT will act on it and the force of water X (defined before CASE 1) and the force due to mass of beaker M, i.e. F1 = Mg + UT + X = F2, therefore the beakers should now stay balanced. So option C should be correct. :)

For all of you who have trouble understanding the explanation...

When an object is (fully or partially) submerged in a liquid, the liquid will exert force (buoyancy) on that object regardless if that object is suspended from a rope or if it is pushed under water by a finger or a stick. And that force will always be equal in size to the gravitational force of the displaced liquid.

Acrylic ball is fully submerged, so the buoyancy will be equal to the gravitational force of a ball made out of water with the same dimensions as the acrylic ball (i.e. displaced amount of water). That makes the acrylic side of the scale heavier exactly by the displaced amount of water. Acrylic is more dense than water but the remaining weight of the ball is suspended on the rope, so that extra weight does not effect the scale.

I see that some people think that the whole weight of the acrylic ball is supported by the rope. That is not the case. As soon as you displace water, that results in buoyancy, even if the submerged object is denser than water. Think of it this way; if you suspend a ping pong ball from a rope and dip it in water, you wouldn't expect the ping pong ball to sink, just because the weight of the ball is supported by the rope and that therefore the water would have no effect on the ping pong ball. The ping pong will in fact float on the water regardless of if it is suspended by a rope or not. So why would then acrylic ball not experience any buoyancy just because it's attached to a rope even though it is displacing water? It wouldn't.

Now onto the ping pong ball side. It is true that the ping pong ball is displacing the same amount of water as acrylic ball (since they are identical in size). But the difference is that the ping pong ball is only submerged in water because it is attached to the bottom of a beaker, therefore the weight of the extra displaced amount of water is countered by the force of the ping pong ball pulling the beaker up. You can think of it this way; if you stand on a scale and apply a downward force on your head with your hands, that won't make you heavier. You also can't make yourself lighter or even lift yourself by grabbing your legs and trying to lift them. I think that's what you call a closed system. Even though you can easily lift yourself off the ground if you hang onto a rope, you can't lift yourself by pulling your legs up. The same thing applies to the ping pong ball side of the scale. The beaker filled with water can't make itself heavier by pulling a floating ping pong ball under the water.

So on the acrylic ball side we added weight of the water that was displaced by the acrylic ball, and on the ping pong ball side we added the weight of the ping pong ball. That makes the balance tip to the acrylic ball side. (I ignored the weight and buoyancy of the strings on both sides.)

Solution for the 2nd problem (spoiler alert I guess):
Now the left beaker isn't trying to make itself heavier any more. The force that is holding the ping pong ball submerged is an external one (you can't make yourself heavier by pushing yourself down, but someone else can make you heavier). So now both sides of the scale are heavier by the displaced amount of water. And since that displaced amount of water is the same (balls are of the same size), the answer is C. Balanced. Again I ignored the weight and buoyancy of the string, and I also ignored the fact that the water gets denser with increasing depth. If we don't ignore the string and the increased density, then the acrylic ball side is slightly heavier, but that's a story for another post.

First the solid ball beaker:
Without water, there is T(tension) acting up on the solid ball and mg(force due to gravity) acting downward, and in the water T is decreased to T-Fb because the water pushes the ball up a bit, making the tension in the string less. Think of is this way: the ball isn't accelerating, so the Forces must add to 0. In formula terms, on land
Fnet[on ball] = 0 = T(land) - mg
in the water
Fnet[on ball] = 0 = T(water) - mg + Fb
therefore T(water) must equal T(land) - Fb to keep that equation true. Therefore, the total force on the beaker is
Fnet[on beaker] = -M(mass of water and beaker)g -mg[weight of ball] + T(water)[exerted upwards by string]
and plugging in T(water) = T(land) - Fb = mg - Fb, we get
Fnet = -M(water&beaker) -mg +(mg - Fb), mg's cancel out
Fnet[solid ball beaker] = -Mg - Fb

Now the ping pong beaker:
This time there is the same Fb acting on your finger, and your finger pushes down just enough to keep it from accelerating. This means the forces also add up to 0, so in formula terms,
Fnet[on ball] = 0 = -Fdown[your pushing] +Fb -mg
so
Fdown = Fb - mg
The total force on the beaker is
Fnet[on beaker] = -M(water&beaker)g -mg[weight of ball] - Fdown[exerted downwards by you]
plugging in Fdown = Fb - mg, we get
Fnet = -Mg -mg - (Fb - mg), again mg's cancel out
Fnet[ping pong ball beaker] = -Mg - Fb

For me this was made easier when I imagined what would happen to the scales if you simply placed the balls in the water with no string. This is much easier to understand, the measured mass of the beaker increases by the mass of the ball that is added. As you add heavier balls, they will go from floating on the top (ball weight < buoyancy force), to being suspended in the middle (ball weight = buoyancy force), to eventually sinking to the bottom (ball weight > buoyancy force). The observed mass of the beaker increases by the mass of the ball in all three cases.

Scenario two is especially important to this explanation. Consider the increase in beaker weight during scenario two. It is equal to the weight of the suspended ball, which is equal to the buoyancy force.
Observed weight increase = buoyancy force of fully submerged ball.

Consider the first case, with the ping pong ball floating on the surface, supported by a buoyant force (ball weight < buoyancy force of fully submerged ball). Consider the forces on the ping pong ball. The buoyant force pushes the ball upward. Now consider this force from the beaker's frame of reference. The equal and opposite reaction to the buoyant force propagates through the water, and acts downward on the beaker. The scales report that the weight of the beaker has increased with the addition of the ping pong ball. It has increased by the magnitude of the downward acting (from the beaker's perspective) buoyant force, which is equal to the weight of the ping pong ball.

When the ping pong ball is submerged and tied to the bottom, the buoyant force on the ball increases due to full submersion and increased water displacement volume. However, the beaker also counteracts this increased buoyant force via the tension in the string. Ultimately, the measured increase in beaker weight remains equal to the added mass of the ping pong ball and string, as in the simplified case with the floating ping pong ball (ball weight < buoyant force).

Weight increase = weight ping pong
Weight ping pong < buoyant force of fully submerged ball
Weight increase < buoyant force of fully submerged ball



Now picture the third case, a heavy acrylic ball which sinks and rests on the bottom of the beaker (ball weight > buoyant force). From the beaker's point of reference, there are two new downward acting forces with the addition of the ball. The first is the buoyant force, as in the previous example. The second is the contact force between the ball and the bottom of the beaker. 

Next we add the externally supported string to this scenario. The force that was previously transmitted to the beaker via contact with the ball, is now supported by the string. Only the buoyant force is now felt by the beaker. We have essentially transformed this from initial scenario three (ball weight > buoyant force, so ball sinks to bottom of beaker), to initial scenario two (ball weight - string tension = buoyant force, so ball suspended in middle of beaker), thanks to the addition of an external force.

With the external string, the scale now measures an increase in weight equal to the buoyant force acting on the fully submerged acrylic ball.
Weight increase = buoyant force of fully submerged ball

The ping-pong ball has gravity and the buoyant force acting upon it, and the force provided by your finger. The finger provides just enough force to keep the velocity at zero and non-accelerating; therefore the force of the finger is the buoyant force minus the weight of the ping-pong ball. The equal and opposite reaction to the buoyant force acts on the water downward, increasing its weight by the buoyant force of the ball.

The acrylic ball has not changed, but here's a rundown:
The acrylic ball is also acted upon by gravity and the buoyant force.* The tension in the rope holding the acrylic ball also keeps the ball at rest and non-accelerating, so the net forces upon it must equal zero, therefore the tension in the rope equals the force of gravity on the ball (higher than that on the ping-pong ball) minus the buoyant force (same as the ping-pong ball). The equal and opposite reaction to the buoyant force acts on the water downward, increasing its weight by the buoyant force of the ball.

After it's all said and done, the only non-zero net forces on either beakers is the opposite of the buoyant force, which is the same for both. The balance stays balanced.

*NOTE: The buoyant force is not dependent on the density of the ball as it might seem, only the volume of the submerged object and the density of the medium it's in; therefore, the buoyant force of both balls is equal.

Force balance on the ping-pong ball:  P + m1*g = B1
Force balance on the ping pong ball's beaker & ball system:  P + m1*g + M*g = N1
Force balance on the acrylic ball: m2*g = B2 + T
Force balance on the ping pong ball's beaker & ball system:  m2*g + M*g = N2 + T

Both buoyancy forces are water weight * ball volume.  Both equal.  Call it B.

Rewrite:
P + m1*g = B
P + m1*g + M*g = N1
m2*g = B + T
m2*g + M*g = N2 + T

Our unknowns are P, N1, N2 and T.  P is the push force, T is tension, N1 and N2 are the normal forces from the balance pans.  You can eliminate T and P from the equations with substitution.

m1 is mass of ping pong ball
m2 is mass of acrylic ball
M is the mass of one of the two beakers of water

N1 = m1*g + M*g + (B - m1*g)
N2 = m2*g + M*g - (m2*g - B)

N1 = M*g + B 
N2 = M*g + B

N1 = N2, therefore it is balanced.

For the ping pong ball, the tension in the string is exactly equal to the buoyant force so they cancel out. That means the net downward force on the ping pong ball is reduced to just its weight.
For the acrylic ball, the tension in the string is acting in the same direction as the buoyant force, so they do not cancel out. Instead they add together in the upward direction against the weight of the acrylic ball.

Let us consider the ping-pong ball: It is stationary, so the sum of all forces on it is zero. The buoyant force pushes up on it. The weight of the ball pulls downward on it. Derek's finger pushes downward on it.

If you look at system on the left with ping pong ball, its a closed system there are no external forces acting on it, the balls buoyancy is countered by the tension in the string. This side weighs: the weight of water, beaker, the ping pong ball and the string.
If you look at the system on the right, the ball is supported outside the system, so this side weighs the weight of beaker, the water, plus the balance of forces on the ball. The ball has two forces acting on it, the tension on the string (gravity pulling it down) and the water pushing up (buoyancy), its kind of like if you tie yourself to a scale and submerge yourself in water slowly, the scale will show that your weight is going down slowly. Keeping that in mind and applying it here, the tension on the string goes down as the ball is submerged, (due to buoyancy) but the force is not enough to move the string so equal and opposite force is applied down, thus pushing the right side down. In common to both sides are the weight (force of gravity) of the beaker and the weight of the water, so I'll ignore these completely and look at what's different.

On the right, there is additional weight of the ball pointing down and the tension of the string pulling up.  Since the ball is in equilibrium, the tension plus buoyant force must equal the weight of the ball: T+B=W. Solving for T, we see T=W-B. Therefore the additional external force on the right is W-T=W-(W-B)=B or simply B, pointing down.

On the left, the additional force is the push and the weight of the ball, both downwards. Since this ball is also in equilibrium, the downward push (P) plus the weight (W) must equal the upward buoyant force, B. P+W=B or P=B-W. The additional external force on the left, therefore is W+P=W+B-W=B, pointing down.

In addition to the water and the beaker, both sides have additional net forces equal to the buoyant force, which is equal, so the two sides should stay balanced.

(The buoyant force is internal to the ball/beaker/water system on either side, as the force of the water upwards on each ball is countered by a force downwards on the water by the ball, thanks to Newton's Third Law, so they are not necessary to include in the calculation of external forces.)

For the ping pong ball side we have these forces:
Force of mass of water * gravity downwards
Force of mass of ping pong ball * gravity downwards
Force of mass of string * gravity downwards
Force of buoyancy of displaced water upwards


For the acrylic ball side we have these forces:
Force of mass of water * gravity downwards
Force of mass of acrylic ball * gravity downwards
Force of mass of string in water * gravity downwards
Force of buoyancy of displaced water upwards
Force of tension through the string holding the acrylic ball up, which should be equal to the mass of the ball * gravity - the force of buoyancy of the displaced water.

Force of mass of water is the same in each.
Force of buoyancy is the same in each
Force of the string might be different, but I think we can all agree it is negligible

I drew some force diagrams and I think the answer is C - they are balanced.
From my force diagrams (taking each part of the system separately) I wrote some formulae down for what the scale is experiencing as the ultimate weight of the system:

The weight experienced/read by the Scale is S. The Weight of the jug (and water) is J. The weight of the ping-pong ball is P. The weight of the Acrylic ball is A. The Buoyancy force for the ball sized water is B.

For the Acryllic:
S = J + B
The Scale has to support the Water and Jug, as well the countered buoyancy force but the weight of the Acrylic ball is supported by the tension in the string.

For the ping-pong ball without the finger:
S = J + P
Here the Scale supports the Water and Jug, and the mass of the ping-pong ball in the form of a buoyancy force from the partial submersion.

For the ping-pong ball with the finger holding it down:
S = J + B
Here the finger adds a new force, F, on the ball equal to the difference in buyancy force from a displacement of water of volume from partial to full submersion.
F = B - P
The Force exerted by the water is the buoyancy force, B, equal to the force of the finger, F, plus the weight of the ping-pong ball, P.
B = F + P = (B - P) + P = B
So the force of weight of the ping-pong ball down is supported by the water (and in turn scales) but is represented by the buoyancy force.
i.e. The Scales are supporting the weight of the Water and Jug, J, the weight of the ping-pong ball, P, and the downward force from the finger, F; but the latter two are equal to the buoyancy force.
S = J + F + P = J + (B - P) + P = J + B

Therefore the weight exerted on/read by the scales is the same for both systems:
S = J + B
So they are balanced.

When the acrylic ball is supported by the string, the forces experienced are buoyancy, the tension of the string pulling up and the balls own weight.
Therefore buoyancy + tension of string = weight of ball + opposite buoyancy

The ping pong ball is pushed up by the water with force W and down by gravity by P, so you push it down with force W-P. So the left scale has weight R + P + (W-P) = R+W.
The acrylic ball is pushed up by the water with force W and down by gravity with force A so the string pulls it up with force A-W. So the right scale is force R + A - (A-W) = R+W.
R+W = R+W so answer C.

C. What a fun experiment! I propose the following, equivalent, but imo more intuitive explanation to the original question:

When the left beaker with the ping pong ball bound to the beaker goes down by one millimeter (just an arbitrary small delta), then all the water in the beaker will move down by one millimeter. Similarly when the left beaker moves up by one millimeter.

However, when the right beaker moves down one millimeter, some of the water has to flow around the stationary ball. Because of that, on average, the water particles in the right beaker move down by more than one millimeter. (Water above the ball is replaced by water below the ball, effectively "skipping" over the height of the ball.) Similarly when the right beaker moves up by one millimeter.

So when the scale moves the left beaker up by one millimeter, it lifts all the water in the left beaker by one millimeter, but at the same time the water in the beaker right moves down by more than one millimeter. This has the same effect as if the water in the right beaker would sit on a longer lever on a seesaw.

As far as we are concerned in this experiment, the weight of the two balls is not relevant. (The right ball could also be a ping pong ball that is simply pushed into the water with a stick instead of being supported by a rope. It just needs to be stationary object with respect to the scale, so the water moves around it when the beaker moves.)

So the relevant thing in this experiment is that the left ball moves with the beaker and the right one is stationary. When pushing down the ping-pong ball with your fingers you create the same situation on both sides: A stationary ball that does not move with the beaker. So the answer to the second question is C.

1.(ping-pong ball with the string) - The force on the scale plate is equal to the weight of the beaker + water + ping-pong ball.

As you previously said, the additional mass from the acrylic ball on the right is equal to the mass of the volume of water being displaced  (aka equal in magnitude and opposite in direction to the buoyant force). As for the ping-pong ball, the tension in the string compensated for the difference between the buoyant force and the mass of the ping-pong ball; thus, the tension in the string was an upward force on the beaker and downward force on the ball. In this case, however, there is no string. The additional force that is applied by your fingers is now applying the same force that the tension in the string was applying to the ball previously; a downward force equal to the difference between the buoyant force and the mass of the ping-pong ball. Therefore, the net increase in downward force for the beaker on the left is ALSO equal to the mass of the volume of water being displaced (aka equal in magnitude and opposite in direction to the buoyant force). As such, both beakers are increased in mass by the magnitude of the buoyant force, and therefore the two beakers will be balanced in mass.
